Posts.Content: I don't want to put a damper on optimism but unfortunately if you have one of the problems mentioned by Dreamthief, you may have to be prepared for this to continue for a long time. I am now 8 months post taxotere but my feet are still peeling. Most days they burn. There is a red line( although its a bit paler at last) all around the sides of my feet. I described the original pain like standing in a bowl of boiling water for about 3 weeks and that's what the red line looks as if I've done! When they're not burning, they are freezing cold and I get a lot of pins and needles or numbness. I have found a soft fleece, ( like imitation sheep wool) has been good in bed to stop the sheets rubbing. I wear quite flat shoes to walk. If you are having difficulties walking be careful. Walking badly to avoid the foot pain, I pulled the tendons at the top of my leg. I am still going to the physio for that. It did get better but just as my feet have improved from time to time, about 10 days ago, everything flared up again and I feel I am back at the beginning. I have spoken to my GP who has only been able to prescribe strong pain killers. It may go. It may not. I'm sorry to make it sound depressing.I don't want to worry those readers who haven't started taxotere yet. For most people the symptoms are not this severe. One or two people have already written that their feet peeled a bit and it stopped. At radiotherapy, no one else had any problems with their feet. The technicians all looked at mine. They hadn't seen peeling like it. They are dealing with hundreds of patients. It just shows that for most people this side effect stays away. But if you have it, you will know about it. You will sadly have to deal with it for some time.  I just seem to have got used to the discomfort. Moisturise often. Get a chiropodist to treat your nails and pamper the soles of your feet. My nails have not been a problem. I used evo nail until my hands started to peel and I couldn't apply it but I think it was worth the daily routine if you haven't started taxotere yet. The weariness does improve but it takes time and even now I have to take regular breaks from chores. I hope your problems do sort themselves out but if not, I'm afraid you may have to accept this is the new you and you will find you can manage it! Take care. Karen

Posts.Content: Hi Jane, I'm so glad you wrote your essay. I'm sure I won't be the only one who identifies with much of what you said. I'm not quite as far down the 'after treatment' road as you are and being much older, I was lucky because a routine mammogram found my cancer early before the nodes were affected and while the tumour was small enough for a lumpectomy in Oct 2015 followed by chemo and radiotherapy which finished last July. But I can still  identify exactly how you feel. The latest tests are clear. Therefore the cancer is gone......and yes, we should feel euphoric. My husband and sons see those results as being very good news and I do recognise they are. But like you, I have been left with a kind of unexplainable  feeling. I feel I shouldn't be complaining about the continued aches and pains. ( And I'm triple negative so all my treatments have actually finished) My feet still throb and burn paricularly at night. The problem with an aggravated tendon did improve but as I did more, got worse again so once again I am having difficulties with mobility. I have continual urine infections which apparently were caused by the chemo and the enamel is breaking away from my teeth which again has been contributed to the chemo. I try to do as much as possible but I am often so weary, I have to stop. Yet, I feel very guilty if I even mention these things to friends and families. I know how supportive they were when I actually had cancer. I don't feel I can expect them to understand now I don't! I should just be getting to grips with life, and despite the aches and mobility issues, live again. In addition, on this site , there are several ladies who have secondary cancers whose situation is so much worse than my own, that  I feel even more guilty for wanting to scream at the way the cancer treatments have affected my body. What can we do about it Jane? ......Probably nothing.....We  probably need to go on showing a positive front to the outside world. It probably wouldn't help us much if we disillusion our families who now think we're fine. But thankfully there is this site, where just occasionally we can show our exasperation at this horrible illness and discover we are far from alone in our feelings and our worries. I wish you Jane as pain free 2017 as is possible. At least for the present we are both cancer free. We've endured some pretty gruelling treatments and actually a year is not so long in the long term scheme of things. On the days our aches are at their most persistent, we will have to remember that they will probably lessen with time, because  time is what this unpleasant cancer treatment has actually given us! Good luck for that future. Love Karen

Posts.Content: Hi Wombat, I just wanted to reassure you. Even the most supportive of husbands have bad days! Mine has been a real strength throughout. An insulin dependant diabetic he wasn't phased by illness. From the beginning he has looked everything up and has always been prepared for what is happening to me because he'd researched the procedures. When we saw specialists, he could ask the questions I didn't know about. BUT he had his bad days too. He worried about the outcome but it wasn't very macho to discuss his fears on 'a men's night ' out. It wasn't exactly that he wasn't sympathetic about the continual aches and pains, it was just to him the main cancer was being dealt with and I was going to get better in his mind so I needed to be positive to keep moving forward. There were certainly days when I commented about things people were suffereing on Macmillan, that he asked me to put it away. To try and live without thinking about cancer. Of course we know that's impossible but he saw it as a kind of ' out of sight, out of mind' scenario. If we didn't dwell on it.....it wouldn't happen!  He wasn't like that often. When the chemo made me very sick, when the taxotere effected my feet and hands, when I aggravated the tendon in my leg which has made mobility difficult, he was extremely understanding. He didn't expect me to do more than I could and did as much as he could to enable it. It was just occasionally that it all got too much for him too. And that seemed to manifest in the kind of outbursts you decribe......' what about me?'  Perhaps if we're in a partnership, difficult though it is because its only one half that has the illness, we need to remember that the other half has feelings too. Often feelings of being unable to help us when we look desperately ill but that there will also  be times when they can't see quite how unwell we feel and expect us to be more positive.  We  got through it by talking. I tried to explain how debilitating the aches, which he couldn't see, made me feel so he could understand better. And he told me how worried he was that the treatment wouldn't work and after 42 years he would lose me. But he also told me, he didn't want me to know he was worried. Luckily he can stop worrying now. My last mammogram shows for the time being the cancer is gone! Nowadays I am trouble because I continue to follow your stories and offer anecdotes if I can. He says it won't help me, despite possibly helping someone else leave the cancer behind.. I forsee another little 'talk' is required! Hope things go better for you today and it helps to know your situation has been shared. Love Karen

Posts.Title: Third year mammogram

Posts.Content: Hello, It is a while since I have posted partly because  I have had an unrelated health problem and partly because I have been getting on with living! But I know how worrying it is when you have just been diagnosed or are feeling dreadful during chemo or radiotherapy so I thought I would just like to tell you that despite all these difficult days, there is light at the end of the tunnel. We sadly frequently hear from those who are unlucky enough for the cancer to cause continuing problems but not so often from those whose cancer has gone and is staying away. Today I had my third year mammogram followed by an ultrasound. It is still clear. My cancer has still gone. I have made a few changes to things I eat( dairy free) and products I buy ( paraben free) acting on advise but gradually over the last 18 months my energy levels have returned and my life back on track to be enjoyed. By coincidence it was exactly three years ago today I had my operation. Yes, the shock of finding the cancer makes you appreciate all the good things you have  and probably I do more now rather than delay them for another time. I also have been determined to say to well wishers who ask me how the cancer is going to reply that I haven't had cancer since the day the surgeon took the tumours away and the treatment was to prevent it's return.  Of course I know there is a chance it could still come back but it hasn't yet. I hope that will give encouragement to those of you who are beginning your treatments. I found it encouraging when a lady at my church told me she had had breast cancer 28 years previously. She also told me that she could have spent the years miserably worrying about the ' what if's' or she could do what she had done.....get on and enjoy every cancer free day she was offered. Amazing reassuring advice.....I am definitely trying to follow it and I hope you too will be able to look on the other side of the rough days, the worries and the discomforts and reach the day when like me you can say ' 3 years cancer free' because I'm sure you will get there too. My wishes to you all for successful treatments. Karen

Posts.Content: I agree with Ronstar when she says she had a healthy diet and still got cancer as I thought we did too so where does that leave us? My husband has been insulin dependent for the last 35 years so we have plenty of fruit and veg, low sugar, low fat, variety of protein, some meat free days. I cook ' home recipes' most meals. But still the cancer came. So we decided, having read a few reviews, that we would not get obsessed but would introduce a few changes where appropriate.  We reduced dairy by swapping breakfast milk to almond milk on cereal and porridge but not in tea. We changed yogurts to soya, and single cream in recipes( sauces, quiches etc) to soya cuisine.We use a cholesterol reducing spread instead of butter for both spreading and cooking. I reduced alcohol but I didn't drink a lot and this reduction was as much about taste as a healthy option. We have at least one veggie meal a week and very little red meat using white meats and fish instead.  We always buy fresh vegetables and eat a large variety. We don't have large quantities of bread but buy either cereal or nutbread. Will it stop the cancer returning? ( I am triple negative) I'll tell you in 4 years time but at least I feel good that I've made a bit of effort to help myself. Karen

Posts.Content: Hello, I struggled too to keep down fluids after all my chemo doses. Each time for several hours even a sip of water made me sick. Although I had Emend from the first dose, I was still very sick and once I couldn't take a sip of water, I couldn't take more anti sickness pills. If this happens to you, you must make sure you monitor your temperature........mine got very close to the 'alarm' point on several occasions but luckily just stayed below. Once I had stopped vomiting after each sip of liquid, my husband made me a warm liquid sugar drink ( he is diabetic and buys sugar syrup for his sugar control) As well as replacing liquid, this gave me some energy as well. I didn't have very much to begin with but it was a start. Gradually we added infusions of ginger lemon tea. Most times I was unwell for 5-7 days and it was 10 days before I went out. Unfortunately, I didn't find this web site until I had already had 3 doses. Hopefully you will find some helpful hints earlier! I think if you are prone to sickness, as I have always been, it is very difficult to get through chemo without.  However, it passes. However awful you feel today, in a few months time, it will be over. I have now finished all my treatment and have just returned from a long holiday in Italy and the south of France. There are still foods and drinks I used to love which I don't like now but mostly things are back to normal. I hope you start to feel better soon. At least you have been able to use the internet......the lights and movement on my tablet screen made me very sick! Love Karen

Posts.Content: Hi Jemily, In my view you've more than passed the first test! What a lovely daughter you are........here you are asking immediately what can I do and will I be able to do it. Together you and your mum will work out what she needs. My experience from life is, that if you have to do something,you can. So please stop worrying yourself. You're going to make a great team. If I moved on my own I was sick so it was great he was happy to help me to the bathroom and wait outside, then help me back. He brought me plenty of water to drink. He tried to tempt me to eat with toast or scrambled eggs. I didn't have to do anything. One area though  where my 'men' failed was helping me to wash when I was feeling very sick. I had a few accidents on the way to the toilet and could have done with a bit of female assistance. If you are aware this might happen to your mum, you can probably ask her from time to time, if she needs help., She will probably want to paint her nails daily with 2 coates of evonail. Maybe something else you can do. I always make a mess of my left hand! And remember........we are all different. She may not have more than a little nausea and then she will just need your company. You will probably have read, like I have, how difficult some ladies' families are towards them so its lovely to read how much you care and much support your mum is going to have. At home, we've revised our diet and although its not drastic changes or banning anything, its much healthier. I have overhauled my friendship list. Cancer certainly sorted the chaff from the wheat! I have made new friends through the cancer. Some who had always been there, I just hadn't recognised their quiet presence until it was needed and some new. In my case, as a family, we have been brought together and that's a relationship I hope will continue. It was good to see how my sons rallied around their Dad to support him and in turn help me. I am already retired so don't have work to return too but I'm not going to waste my time. I've joined a book group and next week I'm going to try the Aqua gym.( Try because my energy levels haven't quite returned to pre cancer amounts) I have another 10 sessions of shock waves on my tendon but it is improving so hopefully that will clear it. So Loupielou, as we get ourselves through these quite anxious, waiting, weeks, I wish you every happiness for a long future! This is the point where actually we have to be positive....( horribly overused word!)......the shape of that future depends on it! Takecare Love Karen

Posts.Content: Tzxy.......I was very apprehensive about the removal of my port. I had had it fitted under general anesthetic but it was to be removed by a local. I worried for nothing. The surveon who inserted it, removed it. He was so gentle and so considerate making sure no blood would get on my clothes. Because mine was quite high at collar bone level, I couldn't see what he was doing but I felt nothing and suddenly it was done.  I think a port is the best way to have chemo.It's under the skin so doesn't prevent you doing anything. Nothing has to be flushed until your session in the chemo. The chemo becomes painless. Where I live,it's standard. Everyone has one without choice so when I was first diagnosed, I never questioned it but later, when I read on this site some of the vein problems sometimes experienced, I was glad Ihad it! Hope all goes well for you. It will seem frightening and unknown at the moment but amazingly, you suddenly find it all behind you, and hopefully with clear mammogram results for the future. Love Karen

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm 63 so I don't work but I haven't hidden the fact I have cancer. However, I have found that this has enabled people to talk to me rather than be embarrassed by it. Some have been really encouraging telling me their own experiences i.e. cancer 20 years ago and still fine, other's have needed reassurance from me that treatment locally is fine but most importantly, I have been able to encourage ladies( often total strangers who are just chatting to me over coffee in a bar) to take up the invites for their mammograms. Not everyone realised ut was possible not to know you had a tumour because its internal. I know that doesn't help Lizz and Sarah with your scarf in school problem, but I do think , if it was me, I would discuss it with whoever in charge and ask for their advise and suggested solutions.  I am a little ahead of you on the treatment ladder and technically its finished but I still find, if I spend too much time doing normal things out of the house, the fatigue just kicks in and I have no control over it and have to rest. I wouldn't want to working somewhere where no one knew why I felt like that. I also believe cancer is so common now and often so treatable, it shouldn't be hidden but mentioned like flu, so that it can be accepted and not a cause for hushed whispers and fear. Posts.Title: Picc line for chemo

Posts.Content: Hi, I am 64. I think in your position I would think about having the radiotherapy. If you follow the preparatory instructions and use a good cream after each session( in France we are prescribed 100% hyaluronique) you shouldn't have any problems and it is an extra precaution against return. The tablets are a different and more personal decision. There do seem to be a lot of contributors on this site who have experienced very painful side effects but the evidence does seem to suggest that taking the drugs is prolonging life expectancy. I didn't have to make that decision as my cancer was triple negative but I have to live knowing that there is a stronger chance it might return within the first five years. The thought, however positively one attacks daily living, is always just at the back of the mind. You don't seem to need chemotherapy which is a good start. That made me very sick and I think if my cancer returns( the chemo presumably won't have worked) I will think twice before accepting it again. I still have complications caused by it a year on. At the time I was too shell shocked to consider questioning any treatments and unfortunately didn't find this site until my third FEC dose. My own grandmother had her cancer in the early 1970's when the only treatment was mastectomy but she lived another 16 years dying from an unrelated illness in her mid 80's.So it is possible to survive without medical assistance.  I wish you luck with your decision. It won't be an easy one and it will be interesting to see how others reply. However, I suspect the people you really need to chat too, those who have turned down treatment ,will probably not feel the need to  be using this site either. Best wishes for the future. Love Karen

Posts.Content: Yes. I had the portacath. It was standard practice here so I wasn't offered a choice just booked in to see the surgeon, 2 weeks before chemo started. The real advantage, apart from being fitted under a general anesthetic so you feel nothing, is that its under the skin. I put on a local anesthetic patch an hour before I went for each chemo and I felt nothing. It only needs flushing when they give you the chemo and as its under the skin , you can shower or bath as preferred. I had mine out last week and again felt nothing. Unfortunately, it can't be used for blood samples but my nurses got around my lack of surface veins by using a needle designed to take blood from newborn babies. Its very fine because it goes into their heads. Its slower than an ordinary needle but it does mean you're not used as a pin cushion with abhorted trials. If you have problems with blood samples, I can recommend both. Love Karen

Posts.Content: I am so sorry you are feeling so hopeless. Persistant pain really debilitates you so it is no wonder you are feeling so confused. Like you,  my cancer was removed by a lumpectomy and I had no node involvement. Unlike you I was triple negative so there are no more treatments available to assist in preventing recurrence but the chemo took it's toll and I have been left with pain in my hands and feet and am having physio for pain in my leg aggravated by the drugs. However, I haven't been left to deal with these problems on my own and I really think you need to chat to someone about how depressed you are feeling. Is there a cancer support group in your area or do you have a good relationship with your cancer nurse? I think when your doctor was talking about the 5 and 10 years he was trying to encourage you without realising how confused you were feeling. I can understand that if the meds are making you feel life isn't worth living, the thought of more years must seem interminable but the fact is, taking these drugs seem to be keeping the cancers away for longer. Hence I suspect the doctor thought you would be reassured knowing you could take the drug for as long as 10 years. I am sure others will write to you soon and make suggestion of changes you can make which will make the pain more manageable but as I have said, I can't help there because I can't take anything for the negative analysis.However,  I would mention to your doctor about not being able to paint too because I couldn't knit last year because my hands were so painful but I was prescribed Lyrica and now the pain can be managed.  I can  tell you that the reason I came back onto this site tonight was because my second year control mammogram was clear yesterday which means 2 years of the 5 have now passed successfully. Yes, ofcourse I wish I was pain free but I am glad to be alive. Please contact someone very soon and I hope you start to get a chance to begin living and doing the things you want before too much longer. Posts.Content: I hope you can get the hylaronic cream because it worked really well and is reimbursed. All the ladies I chatted to while waiting for radiotherapy ( and you tend to see the same ones every day although when you start some will be just finishing and by the time you get to the end,new ladies will have joined) all agreed they had practically no problems. It was only the 3 who used the cream the wrong way around who had difficulties. I don't know whats in the R1 R2 cream but I wouldn't dismiss the one we were using until you've tried it. Its nothing like a normal moisturizer or E45. Its much thicker and some days the residue was quite difficult to wash off. It certainly makes a protective barrier throughout the day. The cotton bra is a must in the heat to stop sweating but I know you already asked about those so you have probably got it by now. I think modern equipment has eliminated the horror stories. Idiot that I was! I'm sure it will go well for you and hopefully you are making a good recovery. As you are back at work, I guess you must be feeling a lot better. Posts.Title: Minimising radiotherapy side effects

Posts.Content: Hi Lizz, My scar is still slightly darker but as Jo says, it blends in. More important is the cream.Didn't your onco give you any prescriptions? Angouleme have been so helpful and I think more informative. I had no problems with 33 sessions so perhaps you can follow what Angouleme told me. The cream they gave me was 100% hydraulic?( sorry I'm in Italy and haven't got it with me but the onco or your gp will know what I'm trying to remember.Its very similar to that) Its on the 100% prescription and it won't cost you. Now the procedure. Technicians at Angouleme checked regularly everyone was doing it in the right order. Its really important apparently. Before you go for the radiotherapy, shower or wash the area really well with a savon surgras or douche surgras. This is quite expensive  savon as it comes from pharmacy ( 7€) but it lasted the 7 weeks with plenty left over. Just as I was finishing treatment Dove launched a shower gel ' protection surgras'. I have been using it since as its thick and creamy but I don't know how it would have compaired with the soap during the actual treatment. Anyway, the technician explained to me the significance of washing everything off the skin, it helps prevent burning. Unlike sunburn which is the term they always used to describe anyone unlucky enough to react, the skin must be cream free for the treatment. After the treatment apply it liberally twice a day. Remove again before next session. When I was going 3 French ladies had misunderstood and burned terribly because they put the cream on before they went. The technicians came around again that morning and checked we all knew what we were doing. I also had a prescription for some hydroplats which were like cooling plastic to put on anytime things got sore but I never opened the packet until I got stung by a wasp 3 weeks ago and needed something to cool the burning! I suppose the reaction to theradiotherapy may depend on the age of the machine. At Angouleme they are relatively new. My chemo onco told me the radiotherapy onco is her husband and he insisted on new machines when he took charge.  I found the 7 weeks passed very quickly. I had a taxi and I know you will be entitled to one too. It made the journey far less tiring. The treatment takes no longer than 10 mins a day. The booster sessions at the end less than a minute. The staff should check your skin every day. They won't let you burn. On a day when I had a little redness over the lymph node scar, they gave me a small tube of even stronger cream to put over it. It was back to normal by the next session. I have realised reading your reviews that even in France all health departments vary. Hopefully you can get this cream in time to work. I think you will have a few days. Although I did start from day 1, I remember reading that it takes about a week for real problems to develop if you ignore the procedure. Hope all goes well and that you get to see this reply as my internet connection is very poor from my holiday gite. Take care. Love Karen

Posts.Content: Hi, I had 33 sessions. I had no problems. I followed the cleaning and creaming regime I was given. I was also given a prescription for some cooling gel plaques to go under the breast if it felt bur t but I never needed to open the packet. The technicians monitored my skin daily and only once was I given an extra cream to rub over the scar where the lymph had been removed. I didn't have any discomfort but the technician must have thought I might be going to develop some. My skin is very fair. I was blond before chemo! To reassure yourself, I would ask the other ladies when you go tomorrow if they have had these side effects. My husband says if they have, walk away and ask to go to another unit because the only explanation he found for burning was very old equiptment. Posts.Title: Taxotere.........please stop panicking!

Posts.Content: Hello all,  I have decided to start this discussion because I have been very concerned of late by how worried some chemo patients seem to be by their move from FeC or Ec to taxotere. I'm not sure what has prompted this but I feel it needs talking about before someone abandons their treatment through fear. I did have problems with Taxotere which is why I feel qualified to begin this discussion and because I also know that there are many recipiants out there, who do not. I have just completed 7 weeks of daily radiotherapy. My hospital is fortunate to have several machines so it groups its patients, as far as is possible, by the type of cancer being treated. Therefore, mornings in waiting room 1, everyone was recovering from breast cancer. Of course not everyone had needed chemo but the turbans, scarves, and wigs were a tell tale sign of the numbers who had. During 7 weeks I met a lot of people, those just completing treatment, those who began around the same time as myself and towards the end, those just beginning. It was helpful meeting other patients. We discussed our problems ( and our future hopes) just like we do on this line. I never volunteered my taxotere reaction but my problems were so obvious ( slippers and slow movement!) that most days some one asked.  And here comes the point of this article............... No one I met during those 7 weeks had had a reaction like it. I must have met 30 to 40 different people and none of them had this reaction Look at a side effects list.......it will appear as an everyday occurrence. In addition none of the radiotherapists had seen feet like mine either. ( Or the district nurse who I saw for something unrelated) We are always saying 'Everyone's different' and we are. On this site, we often comment when we have a problem and need help. Not many of us use this chat line to say ' I'm fine. No problems with chemo etc etc' but being treated at the same time as us, there will always be many people who don't need this line because they don't have any problems. They are fine and we don't hear about them. Only in the radiotherapy waiting room, did I realise how many other women had had very little discomfort at all from their treatments. If you are unlucky and have a reaction, there will unfortunately be little that can be done. However, time passes and things improve. My problem ( which I'm not detailing because it would worry some of you more and you will know if it develops!) has almost gone. It has taken 3 months and my last chemo had to be abandoned but in six months it will be a distant memory. My advise would be to stop worrying. Taxotere for most people is unpleasant at worst and for many much better than FEC. If you should react, you will know, so contact your clinic immediately but until that happens look at the positives. For most of you when you start the Taxotere, you are half way through your  chemo treatment. Soon you will be on the path to full recovery! Please don't panic and don't give up the treatment! Good luck to all Love Karen P.S. I hope you have this lovely weather in the UK. Its uplifting. I had breakfast outside but at 7.30 it was too hot to sit in the sun!

Posts.Content: Hi all,  My husband and I looked at this and decided we probably had nothing to lose by reducing dairy and meat products. A good, balanced mix seems like a good compromise without becoming an obsession. So we have swapped our breakfast milk to almond milk but left the milk in our tea cow's. We have changed our yogurts to soya which are actually  more flavoured and last week I used the soya cooking cream to make a quiche. You couldn't tell the difference. We rarely eat butter although I do use it to emulsify. We thought if we had more poultry or bean dishes in the week, red meat would automatically be reduced. We quite like the soya burghers. They aren't exactly a substitute......more a different meal option ,served with salad and a jacket potato. We like beans in soups anyway. I don't seem able to buy quorn here. The French like their Limousin  beef and steak hache. Will any of this help the cancer stay away?.....We feel it's worth a try......what have we got to lose? Its a bit like using the mouth wash during chemo. It took very little effort and it may only have been a coincidence I had no mouth problems, but I did it. This is the same. If reducing dairy has no effect at all, the diet is still a healthy one. It still includes some products for the calcium but reduces some of the other, less healthy ingredients and it is a diet with plenty of variety, so we're unlikely to give up through boredom.  Finally, as I still have mobility problems courtesy of the chemo, a reduction in some calories has got to help balance that and soya based products are certainly lower in calories! Posts.Content: Hi Ronstar, You have summed things up so well. I'm sure your piece will have been reassuring to a number of readers. Its great if you are someone who recovers from this treatment quickly,.....who gets back to work between chemo doses, .......who is working full time by radiotherapy.....who is going to put it all behind them and forget it......but the real truth is, there are also  so many of us who no matter how hard we try, are sick, tired, and in a lot of discomfort. We might feel positive and enthusiastic but our bodies let us down and we simply can't do the things we used to or would want to. It does improve. I am having my one year 'control' mammogram next week and I am doing more. I can finish the shopping now. I can get the washing out on the line.  I am going to Aqua gym. I need less afternoon rests. It sounds so lazy compared to those who have returned to work but mobility complications caused by the chemo have slowed me down.  Like you Ronstar, I felt I should be doing more. He told me he couldn't imagine how I could have been more positive and he certainly didn't consider I was lazy. I had simply been left unable to do things. Between the post chemo fatigue and the mobility problem, he was impressed, he said, by what I did try to get done. It was important to hear that. Just like your thread Ronstar. Its so important that those new to treatment recognise everyone is going to be different. There is not going to be a 'normal' recovery pattern. Everyone will have their own. And those who are finished with treatment and still feel rough.......don't feel guilty. That's as normal as those who are back at work.  Yesterday , a friend who I knew had had breast cancer some time ago, told me she was never sick. She had an agressive level 4 cancer and that was 9 years ago. She says she knows she was lucky on both counts.  But you know, however the treatment and recovery effects us, we are all lucky. Our cancer has been found and dealt with. So many cancers lie undetected until its too late to treat. Treatment may not be nice , some of us may take longer than others to recover, but in the end the future is there for us all,  just around the corner. Roll on 2017! Love Karen

Posts.Content: Gloria and Jenny, I agree with everything Kacang has written. I live in France. Everyone I know here has the portocath as standard before the treatments start. I had mine in from December to August. As I had a local anesthetic patch to put over the entry one hour before chemo started, I never felt a thing for any dose. Mine was put in under general anesthetic but removed with a local. Fatigue was a different matter. Even several months after the treatments( chemo and radiotherapy) had finished, it would sweep over me and if I hadn't stopped and sat down, I would have fallen. It didn't matter if it was housework or shopping or just walking in the street. Several times, I had to abandon my shopping trolley and go and sit down in the entrance seating and queuing for the till was particularly draining. It was months before I could go on my own.  But we are all different. Chemo made me very sick. Sometimes it was 10 days before I could even think of leaving the house and then only to sit in a cafe while my husband did the chores. 3 times my chemo was delayed by low white cells......that was particularly debilitating. I was advised not to drive and I didn't until after my radiotherapy had finished. In my case, it would have been disastrous if fatigue had affected me whilst on the road. There was no way I would have been able to work.  Luckily I am retired and didn't need to make that decision. I couldn't look at a tablet screen  for the first days after chemo and could barely look at a book throughout. However, I know friends on here who have worked throughout. Their sickness and fatigue has been very manageable. They have had few side effects from the drugs, especially the tax. There is no right or wrong response......the drugs will just effect your body as they will. I have also known people who were hospitalised every time and I myself have been left with some fairly uncomfortable foot and leg problems, one year post my last chemo.  But the cancer is gone. Life has resumed although maybe a little more carefully with a few healthy changes here and there. I hope your treatments continue well. The portacath will be a godsend and the having new lesson plans will make your return to work less stressful. Take of yourselves. Love Karen

Posts.Content: Hello, I have just completed 3 FEC doses. Unfortunately the second and third doses were both delayed because my white cells were still too low on day 20. However, after one weeks delay and another blood test, I was allowed to continue. When we checked the results at home we realised that I was only just on the right side of the limit! Obviously everyone is different but in general I was told the cells drop lowest between days 10 and 15 and rebuild( usually) after day 15. How fast they rebuild depends on the individual. I have had a course of injections during days 1-5 this time to help keep them higher. I also read that a few foods, notably kale and broccoli, almond milk, almonds and dried figs can help promote cell growth too. I ate and drank them all but can't tell you if  they helped or if it was just the extra time that caused the necessary increase. In terms of being more susceptible to infection, I was just careful but not paranoid and caught nothing. I avoided groups, queues and crowds. I washed my hands regularly and particularly in public toilets and I tried to keep away from public toilet door handles and taps. In a cafe, we just chose a quieter corner to sit and as I live abroad, no kisses!

Posts.Content: Hi,  The mouthwash I was given was dilute Bicarbonate of soda.I'm not sure if salt would do the same but the bicarb certainly worked well. I started it on Day 1 , 3 to 4 times a day and carried on until the prescription was finished about 6 weeks after chemo but, coincidence or not, I didn't have any mouth/ throat problems. I think bicarb might taste better than salt but whatever you use, make sure its alcohol free. My nails have been good too. I used 2 coates of evo nail every day for 7 days, removed with acetone free remover, rubbed argan oil into cuticles overnight and started the cycle again the next morning. Unfortnately I probably should have carried on a few weeks longer because although I had had my last chemo, a hand problem prevented continuation. I suspect another 2 months and the nails would have been perfect. As it was, I got just a few small ridges just after I stopped using the evo nail but I kept the nails very short so they didn't flake and now six months on they are stronger than before. If you are not using a cold cap, now is the time to buy some pretty turbans. Bamboo is the best material. I had a bamboo skull cap I wore under the prettier synthetic ones. I had colours to match my outfits. For the plain cotton turbans which were comfy, I bought cheap headbands from Claires and online. I had a fun choosing bands to match blouses and dresses. The serious reason I recommend having something ready is that having your head shaved is hard. It changes your appearance totally and although for most of us, the shaving is actually a relief, both physically because the hair pulls as it starts to fall out but also emotionally because suddenly that unknown hurdle has been crossed and somehow the reality of the cancer hits home. Having something new and attractive to put on, is good for your morale. If you are not creative choose the ready formed turbans instead of scarves that need tying. There are turbans in every price range. If you shop online check delivery dates. There may still be time to order cheap ones from China but they do take about a month to arrive. Some of the French and English companies specialising in headware for cancer patients delivered overnight. I found even strangers admired mine when I went into town. No one ever commented on my hair! ( And actually my hair is now growing back nicely. Everyone is complimenting the short look. I may keep it for a few months) The beautician at the chemo clinic also recommended argan or almond oil to rub into the scalp and a paraben free shampoo but not baby products as these contain something else to help with a babies developing scalp which is not so good for us. It was interesting. I did use all the advise I was given and also later with the radiotherapy I followed the instructions to the letter and had no problems . You cannot eliminate the way your body will react to the chemo drugs( and I did have some severe reactions which lots of people don't get) but these are areas where you can take control and I didn't have any problems by following these simple regimes. Hope all goes well for you. Let us know how you are feeling after the 11th. There may be other tips that those of us whose treatment is finished can share but we'll wait and see how you react before we bombard with hopefully unnecessary info because lots are lucky and hardly react at all.  Take care. Love Karen

Posts.Content: I am very interested in the ages of the members of your family who have had breast cancer because it matches with mine and also something my specialist told me. My family history is slightly complicated by the fact it runs on the paternal side and whilst the breast specialist and oncologist were very interested here in France this was totally dismissed in the UK. ( see later)  My paternal grandmother had her breast removed during her late 60's. She then continued to live another 15 years. Her sister was not so lucky. With no screening back in the 60's and 70's she had found her lump too late and died.  I am now 63 but my tumour was detected by mammogram last october when I was 62. My paternal cousin( we have the same grandmother) was slightly less fortunate as it was her first mammogram which found a larger tumour and she needed a mastectomy whereas mine was early enough for the lumpectomy. None of us have had lymph involvement. My specialist was very interested in this because he says new and early research is beginning to show that some woman post menopause are producing a hormone which may be linked to breast cancers. If this is proven, heredity patterns would certainly be viable. He thought it irrelevant whether it was paternal or maternal in this situation if a significant number of the same family were showing similar symptoms just like your family Annie. I have a sister aged 59. She spoke to her GP who saw the relevance of a more frequent screening than 3 yearly. Here in France its every 2 years anyway.However, when he referred her the idea of a paternal link was poo -pood. They will only screen younger women who show the other link and only on the maternal side. This is slightly worrying for my sister as she has both a daughter and a granddaughter. Hopefully as the trend in our family is post menopause reseach will have become more established by the time they need it. But I thought this might interest you Annie as it does look as you have this later pattern and I wonder how many other slightly older breast cancer sufferers can trace similar links. It does show how important the screening scheme has become as it can find very small tumours before they have time to spread. Hope all progresses well for you Annie. Love Karen

Posts.Content: Hi Nicky, Don't despair. I have had terrible trouble with my feet and hands but they are gradually improving. In addition to the numbness, I have lost the skin from my feet 3 times since April. But each time its been a bit less painful and the skinning less severe. My hands started to improve as soon as I finished chemo. I know everyone is different but if you look at the comments, Kacang's hands are improving and my feet are too. No one has said.......I'm 3 years on and I still can't walk .........so lets be really hopeful here, little by little things do improve.  I also think that the way you feel depressed this week is also really normal. I have been quite weepy since I knew all my treatment was finished. Before that, apart from the odd wimpish terror, I had been very together. Then I read two or three other members here saying the same thing. Very reassuring and logical really. Our bodies have been through enormous trauma. We've killed off practically every cell and those that survived we've zapped with radiotherapy. We've changed our body shape and emotionally we've run the biggest rollar coaster ride in existence. It doesn't matter that we're arriving in a new place, the past trauma has to catch up and be dealt with first. I think in some walks of life, it gets labelled Post Traumatic Stress Disorder and people get help to get over it. But we were only very sick and therefore the expectation is that we can get over this and we will.......but if it takes a few tears on the way, so be it. A few days self indulgence doesn't  do anyone any harm. I hope you will start to feel better soon. I'm sure your hands will improve with time and don't worry about the tears, you are right when you say you've had enough but the 'enough' is giving you back your life and a few months from now,today will be a distant memory! Love Karen

Posts.Title: results after surgery

Posts.Content: Hi, I was told, just like Kacang,  to expect it take 2 years before I would feel relatively normal again!  That isn't to say that gradually I have more energy, less episodes of real fatigue where I have to stop what I'm doing and more satisfaction from what I achieve. But I do still get tired and don't always have enthusiasm to start things. I think some of the continuing aches and pains may influence that.  I am retired and of course, some of this response maybe age related and I am certainly pleased that I didn't have to make the decision about returning to work. But I also know from reading on this site that recovery is as individual as reactions to the medications. There are many ladies( and a few men) who find that they are fit enough to return working, even during chemo or radiotherapy. I think the important thing is to recognise your own recovery rate and work with it. If you're too tired to work, don't consider it. If you can, and it's good for your own morale, go back. Whatever you choose, don't feel guilty and don't compare yourself to anyone else.  With respect to hair and nails. My nails flaked towards the end but I think the evo nail protection helped me keep most of the possible problems to a minImum and they are now stronger and a nicer shape. I can wear nail varnish now which I hadn't done for years. I  lost all my hair 14 days into chemo. ( Well, it was coming out in handfuls and my husband shaved it to ease the pain.) This was January 2016. It didn't start to regrow until mid August and I had completed both chemo and radiotherapy by then. It was slower than some, as the ladies I met daily for radiotherapy, had hair growing well at that time. But it has returned now. It's in very good condition. More body and albeit grey, not blonde as before, it's very pretty ( salt and pepper shades) and seems to suit me. Lots more compliments these days. The best day was back in January, exactly one year to the day it was shaved off, I went and had it cut. It seemed significant somehow. Closure on a difficult year which has given me back my life for the present. Aches and pains are insignificant in relation to that! I wish you and the other ladies, a full and healthy recovery over the next few months. Take time if you need it. Do what is right for you and it will get better! Love Karen

Posts.Title: Parabens, etc

Posts.Content: Sorry, you were on your own this morning. There's often someone else up in the middle of the night......how typical we've all had a good night's sleep, when you needed us!  But I'm up now........usually an early riser me. You mustn't worry about having some ' why me?' time.....we've all been there I'm sure. Cancer is terrifying.......we all know there's a chance, we won't survive it. The world out there has an expectation that we will be positive. We will be ok......but that's because they need us to survive because they don't want to have to deal with the opposite. Because of this, we have so much pressure to be up beat and determined that we feel guilty when reality hits home. I'm sorry you were on your own but actually whether it was the middle of the night or middle of the afternoon, I think we're usually on our own when the fears and tears effect us the most.Even when like me, you have a really supportive partner, there are times when you can't share exactly what you're feeling either because they can't understand or because we don't really want them to have to.That's why this site is so important. As people begin to wake up shortly, I expect you will get so many replies from other's who can empathise with you totally. I didn't see the programme that upset you but I suppose its a necessary story line. If the character doesn't survive, it will remind the viewers that despite all the progress in treatments, the treatments do not always succeed. Having said that, we're still in a very good place. The treatments are so much better now than they were even 10 years ago. We do have a really good chance of successful recovery.  Look at your own situation. I know its difficult to have to go back as your margins weren't clear and do the lumpectomy again but I suspect a few years ago, those unhealthy cells would have gone undetected. Then the cancer would have had a chance to spread. Of course you are worried. This extra complication is delaying, the next step. You just want to get on with the treatment so that you get nearer to returning to your old life. The tears were just normal. There's nothing selfish or self centred in that! Your body is probably still shocked from the original diagnosis. Everything happens so quickly. I expect less than 2 months ago, you had no idea you might be in this situation. I'm not going to say 'snap out of this and look on the bright side etc etc........'  There is plenty of hope for your future but there is also the scenario you saw on tv. Whilst we stand every chance that everything will be fine,  and we have to allow our families and friends to believe that......we can allow ourselves a bit of realism from time to time......it may not. However, once we've had a good cry, it is better for ourselves if we can stay positive. There's still a long way to go in the treatment plan before you really need to get despondent. At the moment, I am cancer free. The treatment has done its job. You have to hold onto that........the next op is likely to leave you cancer free too. The chemo and radiotherapy you may have to have should stop it returniing. There will sadly always be people in the situation of your tv character( and remember she's probably got another job to be moving onto so she can't recover!) but they are becoming less and less.....and it's not going to be you!I'm hoping yyou're not still up and have managed some sleep now. Take care today. It's going to be ok! Love Karen
Posts.Title: I think the poop has hit the fan

Posts.Content: I thought I would just tell you about a very comfortable find I had last week. Our local hairdresser has started stocking hats, wigs and turbans for patients with hair loss. She has made a private room available too with a proper mirror so things can be tried on without embarrassment and I thought that was particularly sensitive but the find........she produced a little fitted cap made out of bamboo to wear underneath any hat,wig, or turban. Perhaps some of you already have them but I didn't? What a difference it makes. It is a natural fibre and therefore breathable. It doesn't get hot or sweaty and therefore go cold and wet either. It is warm or cool depending on the temperature and it doesn't seem to change its qualities regardless of whether the hat on top is a synthetic turban or a wool hat. I don't have a wig but I am sure it would also make one much more comfortable. It wasn't cheap but it was an investment.  I have noticed in discussions some new chemo patients are particularly anxious about hair loss so I thought they might be interested in this discovery. We have enough things to worry about during chemo, don't we? Actually I bought a collection of different coloured and patterned turbans, very inexpensive, from the internet and they have been a huge success. They are admired everywhere I go and often by total strangers so if you are worried about losing your hair as you start chemo, my advice is , don't be. The more normal we make the alternatives, the easier it will be for everyone who follows on. And back to the bamboo cap........I shall be getting a second one next time I go into town so I don't have to wait for it dry after washing!

Posts.Content: My menopause happened 10 years before my breast cancer around 2003/ 2005.  The nights sweats  came and went thoughout that time so I think what you're experiencing now, you might have had anyway. However, as the years progressed I seemed to be getting worse, not better. I just assumed that was what could happen but then I was sent to a pneumologue for something unrelated and after listening to my breathing, he ordered a sleep test. He had asked me if I got hot at night and if I was restless. The sleep test showed that although I didn't stop breathing while I was asleep as in normally recognised sleep apnea, I was breathing too swallowly and not getting enough oxygen. He ordered a machine for me to breathe through at night. The sweats disappeared! Don't blame everything on the hormone treatments. There maybe another explanation. Love Karen

Posts.Content: Hi worried, I live an hour from the radiotherapy unit. I used to put my cream on as soon as I got home. It wasn't R1/R2 as in France we are given 100% hylaronic cream but its still excellent. I used that twice a day. I was also given hydra plat squares to use on any areas which did burn but didn't need to open the box. The essential thing is to remove all cream before you go for the next session. Good creams don't all soak away. They are there to keep the skin moisterised so you need a really good, perfume free soap ( very important or you will be putting other chemicals back onto the skin.) In France we have a product called savon surgras but I can't think what the English equivalent would be. I had 33 sessions of radiotherapy with no burns but more importantly, none of the other ladies who regularly waited with me, did either. I hope you get started soon Worried. It will be good to get these treatments out of the way and you can get back to living! Take care. Love Karen
Posts.Title: Starting radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi,  Sounds as if you might hopefully be over the worst for the first dose. Are you using a mouth wash? My pharmacy told me to use it 3 or 4 times a day from Day 1. It was prescribed but was only 100% dilute bicarbonate of soda. I know it could have been coincidence but I didn't get a single mouth or throat problem. Later on, if I felt any slight mouth sensations, I added extra washes. Pharmacist said 9 or 10 a day are ok provided you use a non alcohol based wash. I was very sick too. Whilst it is important to discuss it with your nurse or onco and take good anti sickness drugs, prepare yourself for the fact, they might not work for you. Hopefully you'll be lucky and they will but if they don't, unfortunately its just one of those things and at the time, its quite depressing but you know, the eighteen weeks or so do pass. You will find yourself, like I am today, writing back to another newcomer, giving out your tips and clear from cancer, much sooner than you can imagine at the moment! Good luck and take care. Love Karen

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah, Sorry to meet you here but I am so glad you found this site at the beginning of your treatment. I didn't find it for several months and had to deal with a number of difficult questions and experiences on my own. Since I found it, the help has been invaluable. I can't give you any help with the 'How to tell your small children' scenario as my own problem was dealing with a 90 year old but I do know from teaching that children are resiliant. They deal with the truth much better than adults who fantasise around the facts and panic! I would imagine that if you tell your children you have a lump which is going to make you very ill unless the doctors take it away in hospital. Unfortunately to take it away properly you may have some sickness and pain for a few months but afterwards you will be better. Most children will understand that. Also I can't imagine they haven't seen at least one advert on tv showing how cancer research has saved lives. They often show someone very sick, gradually recovering. Perhaps you could use one of these as a talking point to show them you might be a bit like this but look how normal everything is in the end? I don't think I would try to hide what is happening from the 10 year old.  I think they might like the responsibilty of being included and being able to get things for you and help with the younger ones. At 10 I don't think thoughts of dying will be their first reaction. I think probably in that respect 15 - 20 year olds might be harder to convince you are going to be alright. I hope all goes well. I hope you are not on your own with the children as I imagine you will need some recovery time. A difficult few months ahead but lets be positive, you are going to be treated, you are on the way to recovery and a future. If it was still undetected......who knows? Love Karen

Posts.Content: Hi,  I had a TEP scan .....(sorry slip of the language. Its the same scan words rearranged in French) It is the most thorough scan for showing cancer anywhere else in the body. If its clear, its extremely reassuring. If something shows up...the oncologists know exactly what areas they are dealing with, which is I expect why your oncologist has put a hold on your chemo in case she has to add on some extra treatment. The actual scan is lengthy but not painful. I expect it will be the same for you. You need to drink plenty of water before it begins. You will be given a radioactive drip and then you have to sit very quietly and still for an hour. I was a little aprehensive about that but the chair was designed to shaped around my most comfortable positions for back body and legs. The arm with the drip had a very soft , pillow like structure to rest on.  After the hour I then had to change into a gown and was taken to the scanner. It is enclosed but it was comfortable. It does take about 40 mins but my onco had told me to close my eyes and dose. You are connected to the technicians through microphones and they did bring me back and forward into the room. The scanner was air conditioned so it was cool rather than too hot. It was much more acceptable than the last MRI scan I had. I hope having a bit of information helps. After you may have to wait a bit while they check the results are clear. They probably won't tell you the result because obviously the aim of the scan is to detect cancer early so they leave discussion of the findings to your oncologue. Hope all goes well and its nothing too serious. Love Karen
